text.p: These are some of the leading stories in Israeli newspapers on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
HAARETZ
- Ministerial committee on Jerusalem affairs to discuss today closing five Palestinian institutions in city's Arab eastern half.
- Police to question Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu today, asking if he was pressured or threatened in short-lived appointment of former attorney-general Roni Bar-on.
- Commander of air force helicopter unit and head of Tel Nof air force base have begun consultations with lawyers as probe continues into copter collision that killed 73 soldiers this month.
- Ultra-Orthodox head of parliament finance committee holds up transfer of funds from budget reserve in protest at unfulfilled promises government made to ultra-Orthodox, new immigrants.
- Egyptian prosecutors charge Arab Israeli Azam Azam with spying - a capital crime.
- Evidence found that asteroid that crashed on earth caused extinction of the dinosaurs.
JERUSALEM POST
- Prime Minister to give okay to Har Homa neighbourhood in Arab East Jerusalem in several weeks.
- Jerusalem construction debate rages on.
- Mother of Yigal Amir, assassin of late prime minister Yitzhak Rabin, seeks U.S. visa for speaking tour.
MAARIV
- Netanyahu to give testimony today.
- Government leaning toward approval of road construction in Jerusalem, while delaying construction of Har Homa neighbourhood.
- National Religious Party abandons vision of Greater Israel, accepts division of authority between Israel, Palestinians.
- Indictment in Egypt against Arab Israeli Azam Azam.
YEDIOTH AHRONOTH
- Police investigators to ask prime minister how Bar-On was chosen as attorney-general.
- Air force mobilises public relations experts to rehabilitate image of force following helicopter disaster.
- Threats within Netanyahu's coalition to bring down government if Har Homa neighbourhood not built.
- Coming soon: national lottery drawings twice weekly.
